passage.text: How to write an inflammatory bowel disease surgical report
Abstract

The development of detailed surgical reports is essential for the effective management of inflammatory bowel disease, including Crohn’s disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis. These reports facilitate postoperative care, multidisciplinary planning, and are critical for studies on surgical outcomes and complications. A well-structured report should include information before, during, and after surgery. Preoperative factors include team identification, surgical plan, anesthesia, patient positioning, estimated blood loss, and urinary output data. During surgery, documentation should cover unexpected findings, abnormal blood loss, and any anesthesia changes. Postoperatively, the patient’s condition and transfer destination should be described. For perianal CD, reports should include details about fistulas, abscesses, and techniques such as fistulotomy and seton placement. In abdominal resections for CD, findings such as adhesions, associated complications, and disease characteristics must be outlined. For ulcerative colitis, reports should emphasize the extent of inflammation, colectomy techniques, details of anastomoses, and perfusion assessment. These structured reports are indispensable for improving care and long-term outcomes, reinforcing their importance in the evolving multidisciplinary management of inflammatory bowel disease.

Introduction

The surgical management of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), encompassing both Crohn’s disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), requires meticulous documentation to ensure effective postoperative care and long-term disease management. A comprehensive surgical report is an essential component of this process, serving as a critical communication tool among multidisciplinary teams, as observed in Figure 1. Comprehensive surgical reports not only optimize care and interdisciplinary planning but can also serve as a critical foundation for both retrospective and prospective studies on surgical outcomes, recurrence rates, complications, and the efficacy of various interventions. Below, we outline the key elements that should be included in surgical reports for three primary scenarios in IBD surgery: perianal CD, abdominal resections for CD, and UC surgical procedures.
Summarized journey of an IBD patient undergoing surgery and essential information for documentation in IBD surgical reports.
These three specific scenarios, however, present descriptions that are common to all and which are detailed below
Common information for all IBD surgeries

Surgical scenarios involve common elements that must be detailed before, during, and after the procedure. Below are the key points that must be documented to ensure a standardized, comprehensive, and effective approach
Before the surgery
Team identification: Record the names of the primary surgeon and the assistants involved in the procedure.
Proposed surgery: Clearly and objectively describe the planned surgery for the patient upon their entry into the operating room.
Type of anesthesia and patient positioning: Specify the type of anesthesia administered.
Describe the patient’s positioning on the surgical table (eg, supine, prone, or lateral decubitus).
Include additional relevant details if applicable (eg, use of the Trendelenburg position, lithotomy position, or jack-knife position).
Estimated blood loss: Provide an estimate of the expected blood loss based on the clinical condition and the planned procedure.
Preoperative urinary output: Report the patient’s preoperative urinary output to serve as a baseline for monitoring during the surgery, especially in critical cases.
During the surgery
Unexpected anatomical or pathophysiological findings: Document any unforeseen intraoperative findings, such as anatomical alterations or newly observed complications during the procedure.
Discrepant blood loss: Report any blood loss considered abnormal or significantly different from the preoperative estimates.
Changes in urinary output: Describe any alterations in urinary output during the procedure that may indicate signs of renal distress or hemodynamic imbalance.
Changes in the proposed anesthesia: Record any changes to the type or administration of anesthesia that were necessary during the surgery.
After the surgery
Patient’s condition at the conclusion of the procedure: Describe the patient’s general condition after the surgery (eg, stable, unstable, requiring intensive care).

Patient’s destination after surgery: Indicate where the patient was transferred post-surgery, specifying whether they were moved to the intensive care unit, post-anesthesia recovery unit, or another unit.
Specific descriptions of each scenario are described below
Perianal CD

Surgical management of perianal CD can range from drainage of abscesses to advanced procedures like fistulotomy, placement of setons, advancement flaps, or ligation of the inter-sphincteric tract. A detailed surgical report is vital for optimizing postoperative care and coordinating further therapeutic steps.
Key elements in the report
Patient background and preoperative assessment
Medication use, including immunosuppressants/advanced therapies (type and timing of the last dose).
Indication for surgery (eg, abscess drainage, fistula management, anal dilation).
Preoperative imaging results (eg, pelvic MRI pelvis or endoanal/perineal ultrasound).
Presence and characteristics of anal stenosis (length and degree of luminal impairment).
Fecal continence status (stool/gas leakage, Wexner score, sphincter defects, scars, or findings from anorectal manometry).
Operative findings
Type and extent of perianal disease
Number, location, and type of fistulas (simple vs complex). Detailed description of perianal fistulizing disease characteristics using TOPCLASS classification is strongly recommended (Table 1).
Presence of abscesses, their volume, and anatomical location.
Degree of sphincter involvement (internal, external, or both), along with the Parks classification (eg, intersphincteric, transsphincteric, suprasphincteric, or extrasphincteric).
If the rectal mucosa is evaluated in an EUA, the status of the rectum should be noted.
Details of the procedure (surgical steps)
Type of surgical intervention performed
Abscess drainage (including size and characteristics of the abscess).
Seton placement (type of seton, number placed, fixation, and location).
Specific techniques (fistulotomy, advancement flap, inter-sphincteric tract) or tools used (video-assisted anal fistula treatment).
Drawings in written reports or images of the procedure attached to electronic reports are helpful tools for documentation.
TOPCLASS classification of perianal fistulizing CD, which is important in clear documentation in surgical reports.

TOPCLASS classification
Characteristics of perianal Crohn’s disease (CD)
1 Minimal perianal disease Minor symptoms usually require minimal interventions over time
2a Amenable to repair Symptomatic fistula, amenable to combined medical and surgical closure or repair
2b Symptomatic control Chronic symptomatic fistula, not suitable to surgical repair, symptom control as the main outcome and target
2c Diverting stoma Fistula requiring proximal fecal diversion (de-functioning stoma)
2c-i Early rapidly progressive Perianal CD, which requires proximal fecal diversion as a prevention of anorectal damage
2c-ii Gradually debilitating disease Not suitable for surgical repair, requires proximal fecal diversion to improve quality of life and control symptoms
3 Proctectomy Severe perianal fistulizing CD with damaged perineum and adverse anatomic features. Severe symptoms despite diversion
4a Repair Symptomatic sinuses/wounds suitable for medical + surgical repair. The patient’s goal is sinus healing
4 b Symptomatic control Chronic symptoms due to sinuses/wounds that impact quality of life, which are not suitable for surgical repair. The patient’s goal is symptomatic control only

Abdominal resections for CD

Abdominal surgical resections, including ileocecal resection and segmental colonic or small bowel resections, are common in CD to address strictures, fistulas, and refractory disease. A well-documented surgical report ensures continuity of care and facilitates future surgical planning whenever needed.
Key elements in the report
Patient background and preoperative assessment
Indication for surgery (eg, stricture, fistula, perforation, or refractory disease).
Preoperative imaging findings (eg, CT/MR enterography, including disease extent, bowel wall thickness, proximal dilatation, and complications, such as abscesses and fistulas).
Disease distribution (eg, ileal, jejunal, colonic, or foregut involvement).
Preoperative medication: steroids (dose, tapering strategy), immunomodulators, advanced therapies (biologics or small molecules: dosage, duration of treatment, timing of last dose).
Nutritional status and preoperative optimization measures (eg, total parenteral nutrition, corticosteroid tapering).
History of previous surgery (type, location, and extent of prior resections).
Stoma site demarcation in emergency procedures or procedures involving proximal diversion can be described.
Operative findings
Description of findings related to previous operation, ie, adhesions, new anatomy, etc.
Location and extent of disease
Description of involved segments, distance from anatomical landmarks, and functional impact (eg, dilation).
Intraoperative characteristics of the affected segment
Documentation of fistulas, fibrosis, mesenteric fat hypertrophy, or associated obstructions.
Details of associated complications
Comprehensive reporting of intra-abdominal abscesses, adhesions, and the impact on adjacent organs.
Details of the procedure (surgical steps)

Type of surgical approach: If minimally invasive (laparoscopic, single-port, or robotic) include details of trocar placement. If conventional (open) include the size and location of the incision. The initial impression of the abdominal cavity can be described.
Initial impression of the disease (phlegmons, abscesses, internal, or internal fistulas, degree of proximal bowel dilatation) is essential.

Type of resection performed (eg, ileocecal, small bowel, or colonic resection). Extent of specimen length and mesenteric or mesocolic control techniques (energy device, clipping, or conventional sutures) comprise useful information.
Anastomotic details

Type (eg, side-to-side, end-to-end, end-to-side or stapled vs hand-sewn). Location and assessment of anastomotic tension and vascularity as well as types of staplers or sutures used comprise useful information.
Use of intraoperative imaging, such as fluorescence angiography to check anastomotic viability is also useful.
Handling of adjacent structures (eg, ureters, bladder, or ovaries) and any perioperative complications need detailed description.
Length of the remaining small bowel measured by an operative sterile ruler is suggested.
Documentation of tissue samples sent for pathology.

Duration of surgery and hemodynamic status of patient (need for blood transfusion, volume of fluids, and urine output, and the presence of hematuria—can be a sign of ureter or bladder lesion or just manipulation).
UC: colectomy and ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

Surgical management of UC often involves total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) or subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy in acute settings or in sick patients. Type of strategy used (2-stage, modified 2-stage, or 3-stage) is essential as an introductory inflammation.
Key elements in the report
Patient background and preoperative assessment
Indication for surgery (eg, refractory disease, dysplasia, or acute severe colitis).
History of previous operations: details of the interventions performed, and anatomical sites involved (eg, prior resections, other abdominal operations, or stomas).
Preoperative imaging or endoscopic findings.
Preoperative medication: steroids (dose, tapering strategy), immunomodulators, advanced therapies (biologics or small molecules: dosage, duration of treatment, timing of last dose).
Stoma demarcation for end ileostomy or diverting loop ileostomy.
The nutritional status should be described.
The planned procedure should be mentioned, including a description of the reasons for any change in the plan (eg, from 2 to 3 stages).
Operative findings
Extent of disease
Degree of colonic inflammation, extension of the disease (if pancolitis or proctossigmoiditis) presence of pseudopolyps, or dysplasia.
Presence of toxic megacolon or perforation.
Condition of adjacent structures
Small bowel involvement or adhesions.
Extraintestinal complications (eg, contained perforation or abscesses).
Details of the procedure (surgical steps)
Type of procedure performed
Total or subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy (initial approach for 3-stage or modified 2-stage).
Proctocolectomy with IPAA vs completion proctectomy with IPAA in patients with previous colectomy vs subtotal colectomy in acute settings.
Completion proctectomy (ie, keeping end ileostomy as permanent with abdomino-perineal resection)
Loop ileostomy construction (precise distance from pouch is useful information).
Specific surgical techniques used

Open vs laparoscopic approach (trocar placement, size, and location of incisions). If robotic proctectomy and IPAA details of trocar placement are needed. Descriptions of incisions for specimen extraction are also essential (location, size, etc.).
Management of the rectal stump: Document the technique used (eg, stapled vs hand-sewn closuremucous fistula, or subcutaneous implantation)

Pouch configuration (eg, J-pouch or S-pouch) and size of the pouch (in centimeters). Details of rectal transection (type of stapler, if used) and pouch construction (size and types of staplers) are needed.
Lengthening maneuvers performed for pouch reach (eg, mesenteric release or ligation of the ileocolic vessels).

Hand-sewn vs stapled anastomosis for IPAA needs clarification (types of sutures used, single or two layers, absorbable or non-absorbable, size of circular stapler for double stapling, or TTSS anastomosis).
Intraoperative assessment of pouch perfusion (eg, indocyanine) and air leak testing.
Handling of intraoperative complications (eg, bleeding or injury to adjacent organs).
Drainage of the pelvic cavity needs description.

Documentation of tissue samples sent for pathology. Describe how many samples are sent for pathological analysis, where they come from, and how they are prepared: for example, fresh, fixed in formalin, etc.
Final considerations

A thorough and structured surgical report is indispensable in the management of IBD. By ensuring the inclusion of critical details tailored to specific procedures—whether addressing perianal CD, abdominal resections, or UC surgical procedures—surgeons can significantly enhance postoperative care and long-term outcomes (Table 2). Clear information in charts is essential for postoperative planning from the gastroenterologists’ perspective. As IBD treatment continues to evolve, surgical reports remain a cornerstone of effective multidisciplinary care and patient management.
Summary of essential points to be documented in IBD-related surgical procedures.
